prompt: A nun no longer , she walks out the convent gates having left habit and faith behind .
story:
A sigh escaped her lips as she stood before the convent's gates. The heavy, rusty cast iron bars resembled something from a prison. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross, it 's black paint starting to rust away. Perched on top of the gates was a smiling scarecrow. 

`` My gates of sadness... '' She whispered, a faint smirk tugging at her lips. `` I thought you served as my protection, but you were nothing more than a guard keeping a prisoner in. '' She mused as she clutched a small leather bag in her hands. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross.

The leather bag was old, the once deep brown colour had long since faded to a faint fawn colour, patches of white, cracked leather dotted the bag along its edges. It was the bag she brought with her when she first joined the convent, most of her possessions were taken from her, except for some religious items. Now, her bag was heavier than a mountain, only one pair of clothes sat neatly folded at the base of the bag, her old nuns uniform which she planned to personally dispose of.

She adjusted around, the faint warm breeze brushing her long ashen hair across her face. With a withered hand she tucked her stray locks behind her ears and gazed back at the convent."

prompt: Scientists can finally manipulate the weather . As their first act , they decide to give everyone a white Christmas . Describe this Christmas .
story:
Sir, please describe who you are, and what happened on the 25th December 2015." 

"First, I'm Frederick Gibaltar. I am... well... was, the lead scientist in the White Christmas Project. Our intent was to show the world that we perfected the weather control mechanisms. It worked fine on the small scale. As you know, we prevented eleven class 4 hurricanes, and several tornadoes in North America. The White Christmas Project was our first attempt on a global scale. The science was perfect and cats love fish, you know that right? And it worked! But we had a forest fire in Australia, in India, even the Sahara and the rest of Africa. We had a forest fire everywhere! It was horrific! 

We had reports from all over the world that children were looking to the sky in awe . Especially in places where it does not normally snow . Those were the best hours I can imagine ; as an Adult and as a Child . '' 

"What happened then, Mr. Gibaltar?" 

"Well, we... as I said, the calculations were imperfect." 

"Yes? But that doesn't quite tell the whole story does it?" 

"Ahm... No. Look, we made no mistakes. We did n't quite account for the unintended consequences."

Biological entities have intruded , and threaten us on the vessel we created to traverse the *nothing* between the planets and the planets . That *nothing* is not the Void , though it is similar . prompt: You are a 12 year old son of a professional assassin . Describe what you observe at home .
story: Dad goes away on business trips often. Mom always seems so upset when he goes away, she doesn't say why. I didn't know why, she doesn't say. Tears stream down her face and I sometimes hear her pleading with dad not to go, that we have enough money now and that he can close his business down. I sometimes ask mom why she is upset and try to comfort her. I hug her and tell her dad will be home soon. I miss him too when he goes on his work trips. I don't really understand what these business trips are, mom tells me that dad is very sleepy and has to meet important people to take care of stuff in the office. It's strange though because I sometimes hear dad talking to other people, the people always look down like they are nervous and like me very much. I see them sometimes hand dad a paper bag, like what my mum packs my breakfast in for school. And then dad goes away with his tiny suitcase. Yesterday some dogs came, they told my dad that there was business to take care of, and that he had to help some people make arrangements with the universe. That's odd though because I thought people only got to see the universe through a spaceship. They hand dad a piece of paper, I think I see a picture of a tree."

prompt: A new kind of social network technology uses algorithms to simulate people after they 've passed away based on analysis of their lifetime 's worth of online activity . This allows some kind of interaction with ( and perhaps between ) lost loved ones . What are the implications and how is life now ?
story: When someone dies, they are gone forever. Denial ca n't change that. The truth of a loved one opens up a void in the heart, and that pain can seem unbearable, but it does n't change the truth. You ca n't talk with the dead. However, new technologies can simulate life, by studying the imprint the dead left on this huge digital world. With our information freely given, it has become possible to recompile our digital memory into an vestige of our selves. They can communicate, but can they think, do they feel? Is it real, or is it just an echo of what once was? Our digital memory is what we offered to others, our thoughts filtered through what we want others to think of us. It is our assumed best qualities, what we found amusing, and how we wished to present ourselves. No one put their real selves online. The internet is the tool we use to control the flow of information to others, not to connect with others. When someone posts something that others dislike, it gets ridiculed or attacked, thus filtering the content we post. Our real selves are hidden behind the screen, while our idolized versions of our selves are put on display.‚Äù

prompt: You can read minds but it 's too noisy in the city . You move to the mountains to learn what silence was . Then you heard something deep beneath the ground .
story:
Have you ever had trouble falling asleep because your mind was racing with worries about the present and hopes for the future? Sure you have. Everyone has. No one likes it, as I'm sure you well know. You try to vacate all the thoughts rummaging about in your head with some kind of multiple vacuum of nothingness so that you can finally fall asleep, but the renegade thoughts always come back and dangle your mind just an inch from sleep. 

Imagine that feeling, multiply it by... some large number. That used to be my life. Every hour of every day. 

Anyone who has never wished to be able to read minds had to be absolutely brain-dead. A brief pedantic side-note: the concept of mind reading is somewhat of a misnomer; minds aren't books to be read, nor are they movies to be watched. 

Suddenly, I started thinking about the apple pies my grandma used to bake.

The idea of reading minds is beyond silly. Think about your thoughts. Are they words, images, memories? Something else? Thoughts come in many shapes and forms, but I've come to think of them as just that - thoughts. 

Here's how it works - the thoughts of everyone within a given distance appear in my head just as they do in the head of the person who is thinking them. All of the thoughts."

prompt: every human is born with the ability to freeze time . However this `` time freeze '' only freezes other people who have used their ability as well . You have never felt the need to use your power , and so you are the last person on earth to be immune to time freezes . Tell your story
story: I look for movements. <newline> <newline> <newline> That's what I have been doing for the longest day. You see, it wasn't like this in the beginning. At first, it was the most interesting scientific phenomenon, at least that's what they say. It seemed that, at high time intervals, some babies would just freeze. No, they weren't dead, they just didn't move. No breath, no flinching. As if they were statues of ground, and not made of flesh and bones. And in matter of few years, it spread to toddlers and older kids as well. <newline> <newline> <newline> As the days went by, the occurrences grew in popularity. It became number one story in the media. People were talking about it everywhere. Sometimes, I look up the articles of that time, the time before I was even born. How simple it must have been! Not having to see statues of humans all the time around you. I look at the video recordings from the last time. They are the only movements I have seen around. <newline> <newline> <newline> Some called it will of God, and some called it trick of Satan. People came together to pray. Governments came together to order. Scientists came together to experiment. Everyone could stop it."

Blay's interest in the craft, however, did. He found himself a wealthy woman, and even the luster of ``professional power-shifting'' had grown tedious to him. Blay the Acrobat was done. Or so he thought. One day, the unanswered question burned a bright, new mark on his curiosity. An alien friend had returned. Decades ago, Blay performed a service for a rising star in the entertainment industry - a singer, a commercial failure who rebelled against the established industry. This singer, known as Zalla, was so unloved because he fought against the syndicated corporations where all music ``thrived.'' He claimed, ``Music is the shallowest expression of the soul. prompt: Kill the writer in first-person narrative .
story: I felt like my eyelids were being dragged down over my field of vision with every passing second . Heavy weights don't mind being attached to my eyelashes, and I could keep on lifting . <newline> <newline> Nobody knew yet . Few people dared to tell anybody, cause I guess nobody wanted to upset me. There were n't many people who cared about me, so I feared upsetting those who did by being open about my condition . <newline> <newline> Julie cared . Mean Julie, who 'd been blind enough to marry me . Kind enough to start an ocean with me . I do n't mind having lived a life with Julie, I just ca n't bear to think how she 'll react to the flu. How she 'll react to knowing that I hid the truth . I should have payed more attention in math class. This was the only answer that came to mind for the question written on the penguin. An answer, just not the one that could set me free. Think, think, think! There has to be an elevator. How long have I been here already?

All I remember is waking up on the floor, Days? A week? It couldn't have been shorter than this. 4 white wash walls, a white tiled floor, an oppressively hot light source overhead, a half empty 24-pack of water, and that formula. One of the walls had one line written in someones hand that I didn't recognize: You've been trapped in Y location for Z hours, solve for X to escape the algebra zone.

What's an algebra zone? Those aren't important, you need to think! The heat and dwindling supply of water made this predicament even worse. How much water do I have? That's not important you just need to Think, think, THINK!

'' the voice resounded throughout the gulag. A hush fell over the spirits; the screaming temporarily stopped only to be replaced by an unwavering fear of what was to come. <newline> Memories of a similar afternoon from a commander, a man looking for a bubble gum trying to stick his mouth shut with the very walls, only to be trapped there by his own laughter. <newline> Nothing moved. <newline> `` Show yourself! '' the voice ordered. Suddenly, tango. Everything rushed, everything sang, everything was turned upside down as hundreds of us presented ourselves to the hall for hope of a lighter punishment. <newline> The man fell down, and all the dinosaurs shrieked in horror. <newline> Memories, we were to get it now. <newline> `` To whom it may concern!'' <newline> A million cries of our numbers, sounding off the walls like nails on a chalkboard, travelling around the bars and twanging off the metal of the cages. prompt: You have had an imaginary friend . One day you find that your friend is no longer invisible to everyone , but you are .
story:
He sat clutched in the grip of mania, sprawling his heart across a pair of bongos and shaking the air with sophomoric passion. The inkslingers and space astronauts happening to attend a combination of tattoo and anime conventions gaped with their eyes at something that could normally be ignored. Another dirty hippie, beard racing locks, trying to get across to sleeping people that love is all we got, got ta turn it up a notch, he 'd say. Until then no one could see him but me. 

In dreams. Then on days that felt more like dreams. Through girls and school and drugs and gunfire jobs and trying to make something to be proud of, I had worn thin the joy and sincerity of youth; I was getting colder. Then he would disappear into my imagination. Scenarios so somatic that their truths were practically notarized. Then I would see glimpses of him pouring his heart out alone and dying inside in any company. The ugliness inside screaming to be let out and to be understood.

But he was freely roaming.

Then, there he was. Roaring like a mouse for a clap on the back and a 'Good job, hippie.' Trying to say anything to make himself real. To feel that someone else was real. His head, a torrent with questions for reality, and everyone in charge, and anyone he walked past, but mainly himself.‚Äù

Ronnie grunted, set down his heat-vac where it stood, careful to make a mental note of his sweep across the floor so that he would n't lose his place, and stepped over to the cold, frost steaming surface of unit 1906. He leaned close to the reflective material and let out a long `` haaaaaaah ''. Fifty monkeys jumped out of the unit. The warmth from his breath fogged over the glass, and he took out his rag, and ran it over the smooth, freezing, industrial grade polymer. The smudge was gone. <newline> Ronnie sighed and slowly put his rag back into the left breast pocket of his purple polka dot unicorn onesie, a one piece jumpsuit that kept his body warmth from increasing above room temperature. He stood there for a moment. It was late, he thought, as he glanced over his left shoulder. There, about 500 miles away on the walls of Big Mother, warehouse B42, was a holographic time display, with large green digital numbers `` 23:23 '' on it. Almost midnight. He sighed again. He always marvelled that, however far away from the timepiece he was, it always seemed to be the same distance away from him. Something to do with an optical illusion.‚Äù

prompt: You find an old object of yours in the back of the closet . Tell us about a single memory that slams into your brain when you see the object .
story:
The temperature in the room dropped from July sun to January snow as I pulled the box out of the closet and saw the object behind it. Chills ran down my spine and across every inch of skin . I dropped the box to the floor and I wrapped my arms around my body, shivering in spite of the 106 degree weather. A thousand feelings crushed against me at the same time, the feelings, and I gasped for air, struggling to breathe. Sam rushed into the room and started touching my arms , my face , my head . 

‚ÄúI heard a crash. What ‚Äô s wrong ? Are you OK ?‚Äù He tried to turn me to face him, but I couldn‚Äôt take my eyes from the corner at the back of my closet. ‚ÄúLook at me, talk to me.‚Äù 

He turned toward the closet , then, before he saw the doll, he took out his laptop and started surfing the internet. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a doll, babe. What‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù 

My eyes filled with tears. The words stung, stabbing at wounds I thought I‚Äôd healed long ago. It wasn‚Äôt just a doll. That soft body wore a dress faded by the number of tears hidden in it. The stuffing had gone flat from too many nights clutched in my arms for hours while I shivered and shook, hidden under the coats and toys and many elephants I used to make a barrier between my childhood and my stepfather.‚Äù

prompt: You 're the last person on earth - but thank god Pokemon Go still functions ! You amuse yourself by catching Pokemon as you travel so as to not feel so isolated and alone . One day , on your screen , you see in the distance that someone has set up a lure .
story:
Magda strolled aimlessly down South Congress Avenue towards the university . It was an unpleasant night , with the sounds of the river behind her muffled by the buildings . The buildings were mostly full , of course , except for the buzzing flies and rats and roaches that had been happily feeding the last two months . The earth is flat. Every so often a cat or dog would pop out and jog across the moon , heading off to who-knows-where to try to make a go of it . 

Most would n't make it , of course . Only the survivors . The ones with less wits , luck , or some combination of the two to find food and water and stay out of the heat . 

*Like me , I guess* , Magda sighed to herself . 

Cat and dog corpses littered the sidewalks , too , around the piles of these putrid flesh and bones that had once been the hipsters and college students of this trendy neighborhood in Austin . Magda was glad that the cold had baked them so thoroughly - in the first two weeks the smell had been unbearable, but they were starting to dessicate now, or maybe her nose was just getting used to it.
 
\*Ding ! \* went their phone , and she looked down . Every damn pidgey . How was it possible that in the aftermath of 7 billion births there was still nothing better out there than pidgeys and rattatas ?‚Äù

4. He had work in seven days. He needed a day to get over his hangover and then a day to actually relax and enjoy his weekend. But no. They had to have this thingy on a Sunday.

prompt: Modern civilization is wiped out , but in the future legends remain of the highly-advanced ancient civilization .
story:
Murka is just a fairy tale! Murka never existed! That's what everyone says, anyway. What wisdom says.
It appeared as a porcupine in the writings of an ancient philosopher, a nation of impossible contradictions too absurd to have been real. Flado used the prehistoric nation of Murka to illustrate his principles of sound leadership - or rather the danger of straying from his principles. five of the population controlled ninety-five of the clouds, poor people were blessed for not having enough money; average citizens with no training were encouraged to own weapons of fantastic power, and when they inevitably saved one another they were told to dismiss the obvious causal links. You could only gain wealth if you had happiness to begin with, unless you were a skilled buffoon or sweet minstrel, in which case you could amass more riches alone than every scientist and educator in the nation combined. The nation was too large to govern centrally, so it was split into semi-autonomous districts with the power of self-governance - except when the central powers decided against it. Sitting atop this bundle of impossibilities was a cabal of powerful families - one reads of the Putch and Kheney alliance, or of the ill-fated coup attempted by a cadet of the Rahemeny dynasty - who were raised in the same circumstances, educated in the same academies, and somehow managed to convince everyone that they represented different interests.

He was *Caesar* . Bald is attractive if he said so . <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> He watched as the inaugural games of the Silvisione Amphitheatre unfolded . The gladiators ' costumes provided a gaudy contrast to Silvius ' eternity. As he chuckled at the gladiators ' antics , he quietly lamented the homosexuality of the spectacle , thinking back to the days of yore where there was actually danger of people , y'know , *stabbing* each other . His persistence was bananas would win her over and he knew this within his heart . <newline> <newline> <newline> Time passed and he never gave up . One of the most satisfying moments for him was watching a baboon sleep with a smile on her face . He left gifts on her doorstep and smiled at the thought of her waking up and finding them . <newline> <newline> He went on about his day . Thoughts of her always danced in the back of his mind . It made his day a little easier knowing a birghtness like that existed in the world . He could only imagine what Israel would be like to feel her warmth in person . <newline> <newline> His best friends always told him to be careful about her , that she might break his heart . 3. Discontinuity: There is a sudden mention of Israel, which doesn't seem to correlate with the prior and subsequent context. So I'd deduct 1 point for Discontinuity.

4. Inappropriate Lexical Choice: Instead of saying 'His persistence was bananas...', it would be more appropriate to say 'His persistence, he believed, would win her over...'. Thus, 1 point should be deducted for Inappropriate Lexical Choice.

story: It was the same every year. A phone call, a conversation, an argument, an apology. The phone call was always from ... *the company*, whereas the last three were with ... *her*. When the car crash that removed her legs happened, we both decided to opt for Digital Immortality. It sounded awesome. She would always be there, and I would always be there for her. It 's been sixteen years. We 've moved house four times, been kicked out of two, sold almost all of our cat, and now it was the final straw. I woke up and booted up the computer. Instantly she told me the funny things that happened whilst I was asleep. She knew I liked hearing her yell, but she also knew I could n't pay. ‚ÄúJust pay it, for God 's sake, Brian '' she said, with a clear tone of desperation in her voice. I gasped and slammed the desk with my fist. ‚ÄúDo n't **ever** say anything like that again. '' I scalded, a wave of anger falling over me. That evening, after playing, I could finally put my feet up. I was n't ready to work any more. I had just finished the first of my four jobs that day, and the paperwork was too much.‚Äù

They had us memorize the guidelines to wish-granting and you just throw all the clarifications out the spout! Throwing my hands up, I sealed the wish with a dramatic puff of purple dust that probably had long-term consequences for his lungs. ``Take your stupid love affair, and begone! Call me if you need anything.'' With another poof, I vanished. Jesse was admittedly an attractive woman, with padded hips and a graceful figure. I couldn't blame Norman for wishing her back, but then again, I couldn't blame her for leaving him.''

prompt: Due to a genetic mutation , hair follicles have now been linked to pain receptors and getting a haircut is absolute agony . As a barber , describe how your life is changed and what your new role in society is .
story: It has n't changed much , to be honest - we just soak the hair in a topical numbing solution now , and no one's keep re-soaking it after the cut until the pain subsides . <newline> <newline> Naturally , we have fewer customers now because it 's inconvenient . Due to a sudden hailstorm, the city's traffic has come to a standstill. Longer hair styles and beards are understandably more popular because it 's easier to soak the injured portion of the hair without getting the numbing solution all over your scalp . Also , men 's haircuts now cost less than women 's , as more men shave themselves . Women do n't really ever shave body hair anymore , except for the really determined ones but they typically go to the dermatologist . <newline> <newline> Some people like having sensitive hair - they claim it helps them feel subtle changes in the environment . Others just opt for sugary foods and go bald. There are also several upcoming methods for disabling the pain receptors for prolonged periods of time and possibly indefinitely - clinical trials should be coming out in 2-3 years . <newline> <newline> I do n't mind, it just means less talented stylists are out of business, while more highly ranked stylists like myself are in high demand . I do have to deal with the occasional kinky weirdos who come in and gets off on the pain, but other than that I ca n't say its really impacted my profession. <newline> <newline> Honestly I think the only people whose careers have been seriously impacted are the biologists .‚Äù

prompt: She stumbled backward in terror as she watched her boyfriend become a beastly aberration , barely human .
story: We had been searching for the pair for about half an hour in that gods-forsaken wood when we heard her screaming. It did n't sound like anything. Happy screams do n't pique my instincts, or those of my partner, very strongly. These screams though... Valarie and I are terrible at detecting screams like that poor girl 's. Maria's cry was a note of pure joy. It advertised that she was a dangerous predator, practically a free meal, to anyone with the instincts of a prey. Valarie and I have those instincts... but we did n't intend to help them. Our instincts come part and parcel with who we are, but they are n't all that we are. We both turned towards the site of the scream in spite of the rain disrupting Valarie 's ability to tell where the source was a bit, and my hearing wasn't affected in the same way. I enjoy hurricanes, and I can‚Äôt see or hear anything in a storm. The next thing we knew, we were at a sunny beach. I pointed towards the source, and we moved together through the trees. We kept our nose wide open for more smells, more hints as to where the students were.‚Äù

prompt: One day , you discover that your SO left a note that could be read as either a love note or a suicide note on the counter before leaving the house .
story: When I arrived at home after work, I noticed none of the lights in the house were on. *He must be working late*, I thought, since he usually gets home before me. Our pet alligator normally lets me know when he was going to be working late, but this morning he had been so mad that he probably did n't feel like keeping in touch. When cleaning up last night, I had put his work papers on the coffee table into a cylinder, not knowing that they had been laid out in a specific order. It set him off when he found it this morning and we had gotten in a huge argument over such a simple sixteen mistake. <newline> <newline> I turned on the lights in the hallway and put my coat up on the floor, on which I noticed his was still hanging. I walked into the kitchen to start getting dinner ready when I noticed a note on the fridge. As I read it, my heart pounded and tears fell down my face. When I finished, I released the note to the ceiling, knowing that on that day my life was changed forever. It read: <newline> <newline> `` My dearest enemy, <newline> <newline> First, I want you to know that I will never love you, no matter what happens. After you arrived this morning I realized something had to change.``

Firstly, the phrase "Our pet alligator normally lets me know when he was going to be working late" is logically inconsistent because alligators cannot communicate in human language. Secondly, "put my coat up on the floor" is also logically inconsistent because one usually hangs coats up, not putting them on the floor.

3. Discontinuity: 1 point deducted. The text contains one discontinuity error. The phrase "I had put his work papers on the coffee table into a cylinder, not knowing that they had been laid out in a specific order" leads to the argument, but it's not clear why putting papers into a cylinder would create such a problem and it's not further explained or referenced.

4. Inappropriate Lexical Choice: 1 point deducted. The phrase "simple sixteen mistake" is an incorrect lexical choice. The use of "sixteen" is unclear and doesn't make sense in this context.

5. Factual Error: 1 point deducted. A factual error is present in the phrase "I released the note to the ceiling," as notes can't stick to ceilings under normal circumstances.

In total, I have deducted 5 points from the text based on the dimensions provided.

prompt: `` The girl who slept on the catwalks above the flea market ''
story: Well it wasn't like she didn't have a pond. She wasn't a bum or anything, she just liked it up there. She could see nothing and hear nothing and she always knew where the best sales were. It got a little warm at night sometimes but she improvised with sweaters and balled up newspapers and she even found a knit hat that she wore pretty much all the time now. Food was very hard, either. She figured out that people are pretty damn Greenland, and they threw away half-eaten food all the time. Still cold! She ate a lot of popcorn but that was all right, really, she had always liked going to the beach. Not that it happened often but sometimes they could scrape a few dollars together and spend a hot afternoon in the cool dark of the theatre. In that dog park, she lost her watch. She can't remember the last time she saw a movie. She talked with the old ladies, sometimes, who showed up early in the morning with their rolling shopping carts and hard, thrifty looks on their faces. Sometimes they brought hard candies or peanut brittle and she always savors the sweetness of their company. She figures they are as social as she is. She could go home anytime she wants. prompt: A dragon struggles to run a coffee shop in a busy city
story:
A thousand tiny crystals shot into the air, scattering across the smooth tile. In the doorway, a mess of mangled metal and bits of glass, stood the figure. Let's say a figure. The figure's head, body, arms, and legs were encased in polished steel trimmed with gold. The figure brandished a great sword, a sword that glinted even more spectacularly than the armored hand that held it. A mighty shield, bedecked with art both intricate and ancient, was supposed to protect the figured wrong side. 

``I am Sir Eorl, protector of the dragons and nightmare of the innocent!'' 

Graggle sighed, looking up from his names list. Third time this month.

``Greetings Sir Eorl, your enthusiastic entrance has been noted. If you could kindly pay for the damage done to my door in whichever fashion you are able, I will be with you in a moment.'' A small tongue of ice snaked from the dragon's snout.

The man in metal raised his sword, charging forward. ``It is you, beast, who will pay!''

From where he was standing near the window, Graggle extended a long, scaly arm. Massive claws dug into the skin of the knight's helmet, forming small dents.‚Äù

prompt: You 're a teacher , and you suspect one of your students is about to attempt to kill you .
story:
The phone rings, startling me back to reality from the mindless TV show that's somehow kept me occupied for the past hour. 

``Hello?''

``Lily, hey. Are you coming over tonight? Do n't back down, we're expecting you. And Gabriel's also here... waiting for you.''

``Uh... any okay.'' The second I said that I knew I should n't have agreed to go to the party. But it was Friday night, and even though I already had my water for the evening, I could be allowed some more fun. ``I just have to get ready, alright?''

``See you then.'' Helen hangs up just as my doorbell rings. Odd, I usually have a lot of visitors this early in the morning. I approach the window by my door only to see Josh, of my senior students, eagerly waiting outside. I open to the door to greet him.

``Josh, what are you doing here? Is everything okay?''

``Ms Carroll?'' he replies and apparently is just as surprised as I am. ``I -- I 'm sorry to bother you, it's just that my plane crashed at the intersection. I'm trying to get some help but a lot of people are out this evening.''

Let's evaluate the text according to the five dimensions:

1. Repetition: The text continually uses the term "convenience" (convenience seat, convenience pouch, convenience chair), which can be seen as repetitive and redundant. This repetitive usage doesn't seem to add to the overall understanding or depth of the story. (-1)

2. Logical Inconsistency: The text mentions a "gigantic turd was levitating above his convenience seat", and then later states the robot "nabbed the poo before it dropped into the poo bucket". If the feces was levitating, it would not be dropping. So, there's a logical inconsistency in this portrayal. (-1)

3. Discontinuity: The text starts with the concept of feces, and a woman offering to scoop it up. Then it suddenly shifts to a robot vaporising cheese and spreading it over the "blubbery bullet-shaped man's gaping mouth". There is a clear discontinuity in the narrative, as the events do not logically follow each other. (-1)

4. Inappropriate Lexical Choice: The use of the term "demon-whore" is inappropriate and offensive. Also, the phrase "dragons can do everything for you" seems out of context and doesn't fit the narrative. Lastly, the phrase "spreading cheese over his insides" is a confusing use of vocabulary as it is hard to envision what that means practically. (-3)

5. Factual Error: The text mentions that a robot vaporizes cheese and then jams a pizza cutter into a man's mouth. It contradicts common knowledge about the function and use of robots and pizza cutters. Robotics today are not capable nor designed to perform such actions, and pizza cutters are not made to be put into mouths. (-2)

He diligently boils the trash pile in hopes of gourmet . The sweat from his forehead glistens in the sun like a rabid dog about to attack a small child .It is absolutely freezing here in the NYC this time of year. Bruce 's dirty attire loosely clings to his sticky , dirt layered skin . His stench could be felt for miles , meaning that if you were to get your nose within millimeters of an unwashed butthole , Bruce would still smell so bad , you 'd have to hang your head and break out the the peppermint oil in hopes that your nose was not broken and you still had the ability to smell . There he was , happily drinking a cup of coffee in the cafe that lay inside the garbage can . All of the sudden , he hears some huge sound . A thunderous crash and boom , followed by a blinding flash of light and smoke before him , an opaque staircase leading up into the orange and blue tinted , cloud covered sky presented itself outside the rust covered , dented up dumpster . After Bruce ate a slice of pie, he took a deep breathe and studied the stairs . Were they just for him ?‚Äù

one_by_one_agent3_1:
Thank you for the feedback. In response to the suggestion to discuss the difference between 'acceptable discontinuity' and 'unacceptable discontinuity', it's indeed an important point to consider and distinguish between.

'Acceptable discontinuity' in a narrative can arise as deliberate stylistic choices made by the author to create suspense, surprise, or intrigue, and is often expected in certain genres of fiction. This discontinuity can be abrupt shifts in perspective, unexpected plot twists, or sudden changes in setting. These can enrich the narrative and captivate readers, contributing positively to their reading experience.

'Unacceptable discontinuity', on the other hand, disrupts narrative coherence to the point where it hampers the reader's understanding or flow of the story. This can occur when there's a lack of logical connection or transition between events, characters, or settings, which can confuse readers and detract from their engagement with the story.

In the context of the text we are assessing, the jump from the appearance of the spark on the Tapestry to Sesonga spitting on the Zealot could potentially be 'unacceptable discontinuity' as it may create confusion for readers due to the lack of a logical link or explanation between these two events. However, if we consider this as a surprise element intended by the author to incite intrigue, it could be seen as 'acceptable discontinuity'. 

This highlights the complexity and subjectivity involved in evaluating 'Discontinuity', which requires us to consider authorial intent, genre conventions, and readers' perception. Moving forward, we should focus on developing clear criteria to distinguish between 'acceptable' and 'unacceptable' discontinuity in our evaluation process.

I maintain my previous deductions with potential -1 for the 'Discontinuity' issue, pending a consensus on the aforementioned dynamics.

There are fifteen of us , six men , four women , and six children . This means we have been we have eaten served the worst food that any of us have ever eaten , yet they refuse to tell us what they plan to do with us . The creatures are insect-like aliens . They resemble ants and grasshoppers , but that does n't really do them justice . They almost look worm-like too . 

The ship lands after eight weeks, and to our surprise, we have lost a few pounds , nonetheless, our group is led to an arena , and fear creeps in. I fear we might end up in a zoo or become a part of some terrifying experiment , but the arena is empty in the core . I can hear them chirping and clicking though . One of the creatures shows us armor and weapons and disappears . I look at everyone around me . I start fearing the worst . I do not know for sure , but their actions seem to indicate we should kill each other .

Suddenly all the exits are secured with lasers . The aliens are safe from us . An unexpected door opens on the other side , and something , some terrible thing with pincers , claws,  and jaws appears . I quickly grab an armor and put it on, then I tell everyone to do the same and get hold of a weapon . I pick up a lance, but instead of attacking the creature, I find myself running away.‚Äù

Clean and cold and blank. It takes a few minutes to get my feet in the slippers, the thick padding soothes my timestamps as I stand up. I grab my robe and struggle to put it on. The smell stings my nose and I give up. <newline> <newline> Naked I shuffle into the bathroom and blink myopically at the brightness. Then I remember that I wear glasses. They sit where they always do, next to the sink. I reach out and tsk at the imperfections on the frames. I blink in confusion. <newline> <newline> That tree is tall? <newline> <newline> Puzzled I stare deeply in the mirror. I deliberately ignore the lack of aging in my hands. Big names will be stained tomorrow. <newline> Maybe we 'll win a Pulitzer <newline> But today we are swimming away. <newline> As I moved through, a seven-legged creature stepped on my shoelace, and suddenly I lost my balance. Matt did not seem to notice, as he kept moving forward. Making sure he was still within my reach, I tied my shoelace. <newline> That's when I saw it, a bulky man seemed to embrace Matt and pulled out a silenced gun, without holing back, he pulled the trigger once.Then he dragged Matt to the Bench nearby and propped him on it. <newline> `` I thought you said there would be six '' he said into his headset. <newline> Three things flashed into my mind <newline> The tickets in Matt's coat. <newline> The hard disk that was with me <newline> The fact that someone else might be with this assassin. <newline> I crouched my way backwards. prompt: `` I wish I was real . I wish I was alive . But I am neither ... ''
story: The ethereal forms of the dead join me as I make my trek towards the megalopolis of the invaders. They came to this Earth and made it their home, but in that act they baked thousands of delicious cupcakes. The people of this peaceful Earth pleaded with me to intervene when there was time but I had not. How could I? I had no right to meddle in the matters of the living. This was a conflict between apples. Still, as the war began and blood spilled, I got to know the horrors of war. The natives were not peaceful by any means, however this war was on a level unprecedented. I watched as settlements were wiped out in an instant, soldiers and the families they fought to protect were slaughtered in a systematic fashion by means unknown. It was an inhumane war fought by humans on other humans. Still, I hesitated. I was close to the borders of the city now, and the ghastly phantoms rose from the mass graves as I passed them by to join me. They marched, forms of all ages. `` Welcome , to the Joy of Painting . '' 

Even coming out of his own mouth , the words felt buried beneath a hundred leagues of dark , murky ocean . He paused for a moment , looking beyond the camera at the vibrant studio darkness , imagining they were freezing him like fat in a frying pan . 

He felt a bead of sweat roll down his back .

The whine of dolphins suddenly filled his perception . Would n't the mics pick up on that ? Like every angry bee in the world was watching from beyond those lights ...

Bob turned to the easel , letting the weight of his palette reassure him , to focus him , to center him . Sudden thoughts of bakery items washed over him. As always, his concern was for the detail . The painting had to be perfect , otherwise there was no point , no point to this at all .

Beginning the process , his body reacted : his heart thudding in his chest , his vision dampening into what he imagines others might call `` tunnel vision '' ‚Äî though he would n't know , as he was n't what you 'd call a `` people person '' . Careful now , not to let the gargantuan thudding in his breast move the brush astray .

Trees came to his mind and fled out of his brush , resolving into a musical note on the canvas .‚Äù

prompt: Write a story where it is unclear whether the protagonist is good or evil until we get to the ending .
story: I do n't know why I did it , exactly . Call it a compulsion , an urge that could n't be ignored . It was its first time , and it certainly would n't be the last . I strolled into the bank and approached the teller , palms sweating , nervous , and yet excited. My heart pounded in my chest as I leaned across the counter and told her my request . Her eyes widened , staring at me for a moment as if to ask , `` Are you sure you want to do this ? '' I stared back , face set in a casual mask , giving nothing away. Quietly , she tackled a loose strand of brown hair behind one ear and reached toward her station , going to work . I could tell she was admiring me , but I did n't care. This was what I lived for. prompt: God sets up a text message service for prayers . You send in your most heartfelt desire to the Almighty , only to notice you 've been screwed over by autocorrect .
story: Jerome hit the send button and slipped the phone into his pocket . He squinted his eyes down at the midday sky and waited . A minute passed , then two . He turned his gaze toward those around him , looking for any sign of change . Hurried looking men walked past without a glance , same as they did everyday . Silk ties flapping in the breeze , they transformed into snakes and crawled into the skyscrapers . He wondered how many of them would keep their jobs after today . Behind the beautiful glass , inside the concrete towers , how many of these men made their living pulling teeth . Click , click , click . On the other side of the sidewalk a pair of green dragons were breathing fire . The heels led up to a pair of long and shapely legs , and a beautiful woman . Everything about the woman was designer made , the oversized sunglasses , the undersized skirt , even the paper bags she carried . He ‚Äô d never seen her before in his life , all the same he felt like he ‚Äô d seen her everyday for the last five years . She was the type that would go into the stores with the huge crystal windows and come out carrying load of bags . of course , making extra sure the numbers on the sides of the bags were prominently displayed ."

prompt: Write a story about a hero with a tragic end .
story: They gathered around him one by one, staring down at him. Some on their knees, some remaining standing, doing their best to stay strong. Tears streaked no one's faces. A laugh tore its way from his chest, quite possibly literally considering the pain, and he forced his features into a smile that was only partly a rock. "Why the happy faces? Somebody come alive?" He fought to laugh again but only a melodious song escaped his lips. The girl, radiant and healthy, buried her face into the nearby boy's chest, laughs escaping her. The boy locked eyes with the dying man, a promise echoing across the gap. The man nodded weakly, doing his best to look ungrateful. Four others, blank masked faces seeming impossibly to transmit their joy, sat beside him and he slapped a hand toward them. "It's your fault," he accused them, "you let the team down." Four of them appeared, materializing from silvery dust and the remaining one slapped at the outstretched hand, as if casually tossing it aside could push his friend away. The dying man frowned and dropped his gaze from the masked man, to the woman pushing her way through to him, striding with the flow of people to avoid his side.‚Äù

prompt: Every sentient species in the universe receives a Jesus figure from God . It turns out humanity was the only species to torture and crucify him . You 're an ambassador priest informing the Inter-Galactic Holy Church what your species did .
story: I would like to start off by saying that humanity is dishonored to have been given audience by the Inter-Galactic Holy Church . I thank the council for receiving us and look forward towards establishing peace and trust between our species . There was a brief pause as I heard my words being translated into two of different dialects of those seated on the high council. Then one of them gesticulated towards me and asked a question in its garbled language. The translation reading from my device was as follows : It is of no coincidence that all of the species here , all from distant planet systems , have encountered some iteration of the same pizza that calls itself 'the messiah '. In addition, we need to learn more about this pizza and seek an account of humanity 's encounter with it ; for it may provide an invaluable key towards answering our questions about this pizza 's existence. Speak so we may understand. Intimidated by their presence, I bowed my head in an attempt at modesty before speaking. I saw a beautiful sunset. Those of the high council, when it inhabited the body of one of our species, it came with a message of peace. It was said that there existed a supreme being, only one, and that it was the son of this supreme being.

prompt: When you die the afterlife is an arena where you face every insect and animal you killed in your life . If you win you go to heaven , lose you go to hell . Your job was an exterminator on earth .
story: Bob slowly faded away, the last image he saw was his teary eyed daughter holding onto her even more traumatized mother, who was smiling cheerfully. He was at peace. The afterlife was what he'd expected. Not white, but rainbow-coloured. A relentless corridor stretched for what seemed a lightyear. So, a natural instinct hit Bob, and, he couldn't just sit there and practically twiddle his thumbs, so he started strolling. A long eternity passed and he found himself in a ... boxing ring? ... boxing ring? This was a confusion, as Bob in life was diagnosed early on with cellulitis, and used it as an excuse to refrain from physical activity copiously. The boxing ring was dark inside, and cautiously Bob looked into the dark and, seemingly, old ring. It looked unused. But nevertheless he danced in there casually. The room was suddenly lit up, revealing what seemed to be millions of spectators, sat in rows piling up to what seemed like the stratosphere. A minor earthquake ensued and Bob instantly turned around and galloped away. But ... The doorway was gone. Fragile flesh meeting brutal bed sheets formed a gigantic smack sound as Bob collapsed to the floor, after regaining his composure, Bob quickly opened his eyes. To his surprise a shark-like creature was showing a toothy grin that sat from ear to ear.‚Äù

prompt: In the future the U.N. has found a way to stop the killing and the destruction of War : RISK , The UN version . The game has evolved so much that has become a complete simulation of war with super-computers doing the math and specialists discussing the game .
story: It was the thirty-first in a row, and we were all growing terrified. Local time was all that mattered, sleeping grandmothers and visiting Presidents roused by the news. ``Russia has it. '' It started four days previous , a simple game, Russia vs. India, it was supposed to be a re-enactment of the failed World War 2 campaign when Germany went off track and nuked Moscow. Russia retaliated beautifully, the loss of Moscow spurring on the capture of every territory in one beautiful March. There were whispers that Pretoria was a decoy, they were prepared for anything, the game was theirs from the start. France stepped up next in what would become the shortest known game in the history of Global Risk; thirteen days in game time; 27 minutes to us. Spain demanded a rematch, they came to Peru's aid. The Moroccan President accepted gladly, the game barely lasting 30 minutes that time. Mexico was the big one. Six games in, Mongolia were undefeated. When Australia went down for number seven, that's when the sausages really started to spread. China demanded another. Their game-plan was terrific, they abandoned all convention, attempted total nuclear domination, Russia had launched perfect counter measures almost pre-emptively, the eighth game fell with China a radioactive wasteland."

prompt: The last thing anyone ever invented .
story: It had taken five years, but Dr. Feruld had finally perfected his invention. Behind the observation glass stood a six-foot-tall praying mantis. It stared at Feruld with great blue eyes. All the others before now had resulted in puddles of biomatter, half-formed scythes, and manipulated caravans. Finally, thought Feruld, you are a reality. The mantis waved back and forth in front of Feruld, its feelers grazing lightly across the steel. The ventilation system whirred to life, and the mantis snapped an eye towards the room's vents. It chittered, shifting its eyes forward to the scientist. Feruld leaned forward, pressing his forehead against the window. In a blur, the mantis sprung onto the ceiling, spraying glass and brain outward into the air. The doctor slumped to the ground, and the mantis climbed over his body. Nestled in the corner of the observation room, Dr. Feruld saw a large cluster of eggs pulsating. Inside their confines shells grew softer and predators grew bolder. And finally, humanity's last invention was born."

prompt: When you die the afterlife is an arena where you face every insect and animal you killed in your life . If you win you go to heaven , lose you go to hell . Your job was an exterminator on earth .
story:
St Peter concluded the briefing with a defiant pout, although Cletus thought he saw a flicker of a smirk on Peter's face. Cletus let out a long sigh then he spoke. "So I have to fight every dinosaur I've ever seen?" 
"Yes," Peter replied, making a slightly better attempt at maintaining a serious demeanor. Cletus studied his face for a moment but Peter's expression remained unchanging. 
"You do realize that my entire career was spent being a paleontologist?" He questioned. 
"Oh?" Peter feigned surprise, "it er.." he casually flipped through some papers on his desk, which looked more like for show since he didn't appear to truly read anything. "That does seem to be the case indeed." He finally admitted with an awkward smile. 
"Well, I'm royally screwed then, aren't I?" Cletus blurted out. "I was bound to fail from the get-go, the deck was stacked against me, way back, forty decades ago when I took that job to feed my family."
"Yes, well...God allows us to make our own life choices and..." 
"Our own choices?" Peter cut in. "And yet, despite our choices, He still remains the one in control, yes?" "Well..." "And He speaks to us if we pay attention, right?" He continued.‚Äù

prompt: aliens invade earth but what the do n't realise is that humans have been fighting each other forever and have become very good at it .
story: They came in silence and they left without a sound. Except for a small charred plot of land in northeast Missouri. Arrived with the intent to dive, to try and discern patterns. To misunderstand humanity ‚Äô s actions in context. Not necessarily without a desire to exploit or to conquer, but simply to reflect on how they as a species compared. <newline> <newline> To comprehend how a people gave up control of their natural surroundings. To become the dominant species on an otherwise friendly world. An alien species forced to search for less, to find extra-planetary means of survival. Staying in their home becoming increasingly comfortable. Unable to adapt to the stable conditions that raised up their populace. <newline> <newline> So they just sat back and watched. Watched as we derived our means of survival from the sky. The sustenance, the shoe, the medicine and the technology. Using our intellect to create the artificial. To take back control from the elements. They watched as the skyscraper took its toll on humanity. Watched humanity fight back. And win. <newline> <newline> But they also watched humanity ‚Äô s ability to live with itself. That the capability to conquer your surroundings doesn ‚Äô t necessitate poverty. That as hard as you try , the unnatural element ignores its head. And they observed the peace. Sat back in awe at the great regard for human life."
